fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Peace Corps Volunteer Justin in Liberia. Mandingo, also known as Manya, is a language of the Maninka dialect continuum, which comprises a set of closely related mother tongues spoken by about five million people across West Africa, in Guinea and Mali, where they are officially recognized as a single ‚ÄòManinka language‚Äô, as well as in Senegal, Sierra Leone, and Ivory Coast. A Niger-Congo language of the Mande linguistic family, Manya is spoken by ethnically Mand√© communities in Liberia. It is most commonly written with a variety of the Latin alphabet, as well as the N‚Äôko script, which was developed in 1949 for Mande languages.
Demographics: 50,400 in Liberia (2006). Population total all countries: 75,400.

fields.Geneaology: "[ Niger-Congo, Mande, Western, Central-Southwestern, Central, Manding-Jogo, Manding-Vai, Manding-Mokole, Manding, Manding-East, Southeastern Manding ]"
